question:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because he has not been able to walk since waking up that morning. His mother said that when he tried to get out of bed that he was unable to stand without support. He also complained of prickling in his hands and feet. Three weeks ago, he had a fever, dry cough, and a sore throat. The fever and sore throat subsided a week after they began, but the cough is persisting. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is severe weakness in both lower extremities and mild sensory loss of the hands and feet. Knee and ankle jerk reflexes are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL
Leukocyte count 6000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 64%
Eosinophils 2%
Lymphocytes 26%
Monocytes 7%
Platelet count 160,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 27 mm/h
Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.9 mEq/L
HCO3- 26 mEq/L
Ca2+ 9.7 mg/dL
Creatine kinase 93 U/L
A lumbar puncture is performed; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 2/mm3, a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 91 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?"
predict: {"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with a history of fever, dry cough, and sore throat that resolved a week ago, but the cough persists. He also has severe weakness in both lower extremities, mild sensory loss of the hands and feet, and absent knee and ankle jerk reflexes. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a low leukocyte count, normal glucose concentration, and elevated protein concentration, which suggests a non-inflammatory process. The elevated protein concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid is particularly noteworthy. The patient's symptoms and cerebrospinal fluid findings are consistent with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the peripheral nerves. The patient's history of recent illness and the presence of sensory loss and absent reflexes support this diagnosis. The laboratory studies show a mild leukopenia and normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, which is also consistent with GBS. Given the diagnosis of GBS, the next step in treatment would be to administer intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) to reduce the severity of the disease and promote recovery. IVIG is the standard treatment for GBS and has been shown to improve outcomes in patients with this condition.", "answer_choice": "A"}
